title: What's a 'Good' Explanation?
body:
## Look at your surroundings.

Now, explain how you ended up here.

Did your answer include the creation of existence, such as The Big Bang? If not, your answer is incomplete.

### Existence

Don’t be hard on yourself. Your explanation did not need to be 100% complete to suffice. This prompt is typically interpreted as a request for the most immediate and significant reasons for being here, such as: “I fell off my bike and broke my arm, so now I am in the ER”. For obvious reasons, it is impractical to describe The Big Bang and then every sequential moment that led to you falling off your bike. Nonetheless, let’s examine the reasons: (1) ain’t nobody got time for that. (2) any attempt at a complete explanation would be riddled with assumptions and inaccuracies. Nobody has observed every moment in spacetime, nor possesses the memory and processing capability to completely understand these events. The main point here is that there is a *reason for being* (not to be confused with purpose). The reason that ‘you’ exist is because your dad’s sperm fertilized your mom’s egg. Somewhere along the way, ‘you’ came into existence. However, the answer to the question “Why did you fall off your bike?” requires an infinitely precise answer in order to be 100% accurate (we obviously do not care about 100% accuracy in all cases, nor is 100% accuracy attainable). This is what we will explore in this post.

### Elements of the Mind

Okay, we do not care about The Big Bang when examining your current position in life. Instead, let’s view the most important part of reality -- your lifetime -- because everyone is the hero of their own story.

Let’s begin at the moment in which “you” obtain consciousness\* (ironically, a moment that nobody can remember). Upon accessing reality for the first time, “you” are immediately introduced to the **cause and effect protocol** of the universe, become aware of “your” existence (‘consciousness’), as well as develop an awareness of ‘thoughts’ and a procedure of thoughts (‘thinking’), achieve (some level of) control of your body and thinking (agency), and eventually learn from the environment (‘intelligence’, ‘cognition’, or as I like to say, ‘an ability to connect the dots’). In this case, the dots are bits of observed data (‘information’) interpreted as truth (‘knowledge’), which we store in our ‘memory’. The connections are a model that describes a functional i/o relation between bits (‘understanding’). Putting this all together, “we” exist as a conscious, intelligent agent of reality perceiving a sequence of moments (‘experience’) which we call life. It is almost as if reality is a Turing-Complete system (a BIG assumption) and our brains are a Turing Machine (another BIG assumption). The one thing missing in the Turing analogy is our ‘imagination’ -- the power to “see the unseen”. The reason that imagination is missing is because it is inconsistent with a Turing Machine, and thus makes humans extra interesting. The brain (our “interpretation engine”) is unique and not well understood. We are also skipping the sub-conscious element of this model for now … but will definitely discuss it later.

### Trapped In The Present

The reason that we care about history is because we can learn things that may help us in the future. We start to learn the code of reality from personal observations. Then, we learn to communicate with others, trade ideas and inspiration with them, and trust their experiences and historical accounts of reality\*\**.* After all, we physically cannot observe *everything* ourselves. Your first conscious moment is different from my first moment, and our experiences may never overlap in any meaningful way (disregarding butterfly effects for now). We cannot recount the past with 100% certainty, especially events that we did not personally observe (and even when we do have an experience … our memory can still be fuzzy). In other words, you should keep the grain of salt in your lens. There are also complex mechanisms that influence our perception (such as assumptions, cognitive bias, motivation, feelings, emotions, and biology) of which we may not be aware in the moment (not to mention the physical limitations of our human senses). Perspective is gained with an account of bias. The famous motto from The Royal Society is pertinent here -- *Nullius in Verba* -- “take nobody’s word for it”.

![A crude example of well-intentioned (perhaps) yet biased hearsay](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/2dSC4WSKaPSXEgp5J1L9A.png?height=1945&width=2085)

A historical account is more reputable when there is evidence to corroborate it’s truth. The most influential evidence garners mass consensus of its implication (a flawed mechanism for finding truth … though it does provide a clue). There is a well known saying “wisdom of the crowd”. There is also a lesser known but equally as important saying “fatality of the mob”. Consensus provides a signal on social dynamics more than anything. The objective of consensus is to win a majority, which is all about compromise\*\*\*, not truth-seeking. There is another common phrase, “history is written by the winners”, which is not an entirely true statement in its literal translation but is an attempt to describe the common biases in historical accounting. The history textbooks are missing many individual accounts, particularly on the loser’s side. This is not all the publisher’s fault because there are typically less of the losers around after a significant historical event like war, but the missing context makes the book sensitive to a combination of conformity, misattribution, and survivorship bias.

![Infinitism  -- The Ultimate Burden Of Proof -- aka The Absence of Evidence vs. Evidence of Absence Fallacy](http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive/phd070309s.gif)

Evidence is built through discovery -- a gain of information which improves our understanding of the circumstances which produced the evidence. It is still up to humans to deduce valid conclusions from discoveries. We commonly mistake evidence as proof. Circumstantial evidence does not have the power to prove on its own. Rather, it can indicate the likelihood of a particular events’ existence, but not accurately until we drop it into context. A proper investigation entails observing each instance of history and each piece of evidence as independent from each other and then imagining the logical sequence of events to form dependencies, hence the phrase “drawing a conclusion”. Every piece of evidence or historical account has a level of faith associated with it (and we usually realize overconfidence). For example, the discovery of fossils indicates the existence of large, now-extinct beings. And we can even imagine what they looked like! However, the fossils and present-day graphical renderings do not prove dinosaurs’ existence. The evidence simply gives us a level of confidence. A different explanation for the existence of fossils could be that a scientist synthesized fossil materials in a lab and buried them to eventually claim fame once he/she later “discovers” them and proposes a breakthrough theory of dinosaurs. However, there are sound reasons that easily disprove this explanation, namely, there is no evidence of a scientist or lab in 1677 (when Robert Plot found the first fossil) that had the capability to synthesize an organic material that could resemble the form of a fossil.

![The Gettier Problem (philosophy), Gödel’s Incompleteness Theorems (math), and Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle (science) all arrive at the same idea from different disciplines -- proof requires complete information and infinite precision. Conjecture is imminent (we settle for "beyond a reasonable doubt" in court.)](https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/proof.png)

Evidence is an empirical starting point. It exists in context. A thorough assessment of evidence addresses as much context as possible. At the same time, there will always be missing context, so we will never have a totally complete or perfectly accurate history. I call this *The* *Theory of Relative History*.

### Explanations

I once concluded that everything can be explained, so the world must be deterministic. I arrived at this conclusion after reading *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.amazon.com/Beginning-Infinity-Explanations-Transform-World/dp/0143121359)* by David Deutsch. I highly recommend reading it. In fact, it was the inspiration for this blog (if you don’t read books, then at least listen to Naval Ravikant’s *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jEmJIA0pEf0)* podcast series with Brett Hall breaking down the book). The big takeaway from the book is that omniscience is not required to have ‘creativity’ -- an ability to create new “things”. You do not need to know absolutely every fact that exists in order to understand everything that can be understood. Reality is most accurately described using good explanations, and there is an explanation for everything. The building blocks of explanations are **[First Principles](https://fs.blog/first-principles/#_ftn11)** -- namely the foundations of science (Relativity, Quantum, Evolution, Information, Computing, etc.) -- and the fuel is imagination.

> *“What I cannot create, I do not understand”*
>
> \-- Richard Feynman

Science is an error-correcting machine. It disproves explanations and forms better ones. You will find that the most impactful explanations require intense imagination because they describe ‘the seen’ in terms of ‘the unseen’. In other words, they describe things that cannot be observed. Unseen phenomena can be measured with special equipment, but we just observe the measurement readings on the equipment. For example, we can measure the temperature of an atom’s nucleus, but we cannot observe the movement of quarks which are the cause (we think) of the temperature reading that we observe. An explanation is not an explanation unless it is testable, falsifiable, and precisely describes a significant mechanism of change (cause and effect). It is our best guess. In this way, even good explanations are at risk of being inaccurate. This is okay because this is how we create new knowledge. A good explanation is our best understanding, our best description for how something works, at any given time. It is like the scientific method on steroids. A good explanation provides reasons and digs deep. It asks questions to get to the root. Try the **5 Why’s method** to improve the accuracy of an explanation.

> *“Science is a way of thinking much more than it is a body of knowledge.”*
>
> — Carl Sagan

As you can see from the bike example at the beginning, an explanation does not need to be entirely complete in order to be valuable because intelligent beings (humans) can identify patterns and make inferences. Again, a partially true, incomplete explanation can be sufficient if we only care about a certain level of accuracy. An explanation is measured by its explanatory power -- the degree to which an explanation accomplishes an objective. The objective can be to accurately describe Truth. Explanations have degrees of completeness based on the amount of information present in them\*\*\*\*. A thorough explanation leaves little to chance. A complete explanation leaves nothing to chance. The pinnacle of explanations is a perfect explanation -- 100% complete and 100% accurate. The ultimate explanation, a *Theory of Everything*, would be perfect. Many people have tried to find this explanation, such as Michio Kaku's *[The God Equation](https://www.amazon.com/God-Equation-Quest-Theory-Everything/dp/0385542747)* (I have not read yet), but none have succeeded.

The jury is still out on if a perfect explanation exists.

### Truth

Our initial guess for how knowledge exists is known as the ‘justified true belief’ theory of knowledge. This theory says that knowledge is about justifying your beliefs as true. It then goes on to say that if you accomplish this, then your belief is knowledge. This a misconception because there is no logical way to prove any bit of knowledge as Truth (with a capital ‘T’). One can provide evidence, but this is not proof. If an explanation prevails against attempts to disprove it, then it is consistent with reality and is probably considered useful. Yet, we can never know with 100% certainty that the explanation accurately describes a fundamental Truth (a “law” of nature\*\*\*\*\*) because there is always a chance that we discover new information debunking that explanation. Then, we simply come up with a better explanation.

The first step to finding truth is to develop a theory of knowledge (epistemology). I subscribe to the theory that knowledge is an interpretation of information that is accepted as truth and can be measured for accuracy and significance. This implies knowledge is subjective i.e. your truth may not be my truth.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xwFu_2fyTN7kfq6Mi8bBH.png?height=792&width=1561)

In the end, knowledge is still just an assumption. Humans seek highly objective knowledge because we get rewarded with better predictions. Nassim Taleb describes a concept of *knowledge iteration* in his *[Incerto](https://www.amazon.com/Incerto-Deluxe-Randomness-Procrustes-Antifragile/dp/198481981X)* (my favorite is *[The Black Swan](https://www.amazon.com/Black-Swan-Impact-Improbable-Incerto/dp/1400063515/ref=asc_df_1400063515/?tag=hyprod-20&linkCode=df0&hvadid=312106851030&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=11165397501409576070&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9010943&hvtargid=pla-330161967766&psc=1)*). There will always be unknowns and we do not know the significance of the unknowns. We don't know for sure what will effect us, kill us, or save us. It may not be real today.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/kWP9k4Mb0aJLmmm6JXgSD.png?height=697&width=1114)

Explanations can retrospectively describe causation and also fuel predictions -→ which builds knowledge -→ which inspires imagination -→ which creates explanations. These ‘creations’ bring a truth into existence that did not exist before (or at least did not exist to ‘you’). It is quite liberating when you realize that explanations are created with imagination, so in theory, you can understand anything! Regardless of whether or not information is infinite\*\*\*\*\*\*, knowledge is not scarce. It is the product of intelligence and unbounded imagination and is stored in memory.

Keep in mind, reality is unbiased. It is Truth. It just is\*\*\*\*\*\*\*. It is the purest form of objectivity (no interpretation necessary). Frankly, reality does not care about you (or anything). Reality is left to humans for interpretation. The most useful application of this realization is to practice acceptance because the world is not out to get you. At the same time, we can effect change in our lives. For every effect, there is a cause\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*. For every output, there is an input. You may notice the continuity of this universal model. But what happens when there is a discontinuity in the model? And what does a gap represent?

### Randomness

The answer is randomness -- an absence of information. This is where we can assign probabilities rather than determinations of the future. The important thing here is that reality is not intrinsically random or uncertain … with one theoretical exception. The only proposed natural randomness in the universe is the phenomena described by quantum mechanics -- an explanation for how matter and energy behaves as spacetime approaches zero. Even in quantum, we have some predictive ability of the probability distribution of subatomic particles in spacetime. This gets more interesting if you consider quantum randomness in a multiplicative series of moments. As you can see, each sequential moment gets increasingly difficult to predict and eventually the complexity explodes, leading most scientists to chaos theory and the multiverse\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*.

All other probability is subject to a knowledge base. This means that any likelihood which we attributed to an event’s existence is a function of our ignorance. When humans say “I am uncertain”, we are admitting that we do not know a critical piece of information that would make the Truth apparent. We can reduce uncertainty and increase the accuracy of our predictions by reducing knowledge gaps (not to be confused with information gaps). Here are two ways to reduce knowledge gaps and improve predictability:

1\.) empirical methods -- inducing a hypothesis from experience.

2\.) explanatory methods -- deducing a cause and effect relation from imagination.

These methods are most powerful when deployed in tandem.

Empirical methods infer an independent factor (causal inference) from observations or experimental results (statistics). This is useful to identify information gaps. You can gain (uncover) information by changing the conditions (i.e. varying the independent variable to see the change in the dependent variable). Here’s a hint, when correlations between events approach 100%, you may getting closer to a causal relationship (though there still may be ‘Hidden’ variables\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* which are the actual root cause). However, correlation is not causation\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* …. so … how do you know if the measured response in the ‘effect variable’ was the result of varying the ‘cause variable’ or if the independent factors are truly independent themselves? Enter explanations.

This is how explanatory methods save the day. Explanations can generate knowledge from information not apparent in the statistics. An explanation can implicate an unknown factor as the root cause. The reasoning offered in an explanation is based in ‘possibility’ as opposed to ‘probability’ (though probability can also appear in an explanation).

I suggest watching Vsauce's YouTube video: "[What is Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)" and Veritasium’s sister episode: "[What is Not Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)" to further explore randomness as a property of ignorance.

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)

To quickly make better predictions, acquire fundamental knowledge. Search for the fundamental factors of reality, the ones with high explanatory power. Lean on *First Principles* thinking or even better -- [Zeroth-Principles Thinking](https://medium.com/future-literacy/zeroth-principles-thinking-9376d0b7e7f5). After all, explanations are the best way to hunt the Truth. On the other hand, we will always have to make decisions with incomplete information, and thus are exposed to uncertainty … so get used to it!

I glossed over the fact that “meaning” is an important part of the brain’s interpretation engine. Sooo … what is meaning? Is meaning created or intrinsic to reality? If we assume that reality is deterministic, then can meaning exist or can we have free will? Can there be a meaning of life? If we assume that life has meaning, then what is the meaning? My best answer right now: the meaning of life is to create value. More on that in the next post…

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

\*I assume ownership of consciousness for the sake of understanding; rather, consciousness spontaneously “exists” without an agent or precise initial moment and is “you”. I enjoyed Brett Hall’s view of [ontology](https://www.bretthall.org/blog) --an explanation of being--what does it mean to exist. The model that I describe requires a definition for the concept of “you” (a whole exercise itself). I use a version of “you” that is a figment of the brain and represents an identity. “You” is awareness that exists as a state of consciousness. I also enjoyed Evan Conrad’s [article](https://evanjconrad.com/posts/how-to-feel-good) which offers a view that “you” are not your “thoughts” and suggests practical applications of this knowledge. “You” observe thoughts. At the same time, you have agency of thinking in the sense that you may be aware of a thought or feelings and its relation to “you” (as an identity that has control of an interpretation engine which does thinking procedures and serves the next thought). I would like to add that you are not your feelings. In Conrad’s view, both thoughts and feelings are real “to” you, rather than “are” or “of” you.

\*\*Yes, trust in fellow humans is risky, but the payoffs have historically outweighed the costs. There are concepts of infinite games in Game Theory which incentivize cooperation in most instances.

\*\*\*We will explore the mechanisms of consensus in another post.

\*\*\*\*Completeness is a function of access and precision. Explanations are incomplete when they are missing info. This is almost always the case when expressing explanations in spoken language because language itself is imprecise. A good question: can we know all information?

\*\*\*\*\* When describing physical reality, there is no such thing as a “law of nature” or Truth (with a capital ‘T’) since the description exists in the abstract realm of knowledge. There are just REALLY good explanations (called theories in science) that may resemble physical Truth because of their accuracy in describing and predicting phenomena, but we would never know for certain. However, there is a Truth. It exists and exists as reality. This implies the existence of False (with a capital ‘F’). Knowledge is abstract thought -- an interpretation of information which exists relative to reality (Truth/False) -- and can actually be True or False when describing knowledge, but not reality.

\*\*\*\*\*\*The more important and deeper question is whether reality is continuous or discrete. This question is most famously illustrated via [Zeno’s Paradox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeno%27s_paradoxes). Modern science does not even have a consensus on this answer. I think the answer requires a better understanding of time and information. Is information a property of reality? Does reality exist as a state of information at (that changes changes between?) moments of time? Can we create new “things” (real or abstract)? Does the set of information (as elements) grow, accumulate, remain static, or simply change?

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*I suppose the ultimate truth is whether reality itself exists or not.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*We may explore whether the inverse is necessarily true, which requires a consideration of infinity. What happens when you consider time (the temporal relationship between cause and effect)? The most convincing concept of time I can understand is that time represents a relation between moments of reality. It is the change itself rather than the moment. The moment is a state of information (reality). If time is a relation mapping a state of info to another state of info, which [type](https://t-redactyl.io/blog/2021/03/types-of-functions-injective-surjective-and-bijective.html) of relation is it?

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*We may address these concepts at some point. We perceive time as a sequence of moments (maybe a series when considering our memory), but time may not actually “be” an ordered sequence of moments. We do not have access to all of reality (information), which leads to gaps in information and knowledge (understanding). Also, knowledge lags information. The Truth Spectrum is not to be confused with true vs. false in logic. It is more closely related to the concept of [entropy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entropy_(information_theory)) in Information Theory.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*A change in the dependent variable (effect) may be caused by an unaccounted or unknown factor (cause) rather than the independent factor. This may be “confounding'“ to some. Others say Hidden variables, once identified in an experiment, are “extraneous” if they think they can be controlled. It is hard to control variables (especially unknown ones) in experiments, and physical experiments are temporal in nature.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*Correlation is an association between sets, not a function. Causality is a function of sorts.

PS: I promise future blogs will not be this long.

如今 OKEx 统一账户，支持在一个账户下进行各类型交易，不再需要在多个账户之间进行资金划转，降低了用户的操作复杂度。

在原来的 OKEx 账户设计中，BTC/USDT 永续合约与BTC/USDT 交割合约、ETH/USDT 永续合约都是不互通的，各账户之间的资金余额和仓位收益不能共享，占用了较多资金。

但在统一账户下，单币种保证金模式支持相同结算币种的衍生品之间共用保证金，跨币种保证金模式则是将不同币种资产统一折合成美元价值，实现不同结算币种的所有衍生品之间共享保证金，由此减少了资金占用，提高了资金的利用效率，用户可以用这些资金来撬动更大收益。

![](https://assets.matters.news/embed/3e6938e6-c01e-4459-aad8-2cac8c92c215.png)

保证金和收益的共享，降低了用户爆仓风险。特别是经常夜间出现「插针」行情，保证金共享可以减少插针爆仓的情况。

当然，也有不少用户是高风险偏好者，喜欢用 100 USDT等少量资金加上高杆杆，以小搏大。统一账户也同时设有逐仓模式，小仓位爆仓不会影响其余资金安全，隔离风险。

假设我拥有 1000 个 OKB 作为保证金（单价 20 美元） ，想要做多购买 1 ETH（单价 1800 美元），但 OKEx 并没有 ETH/OKB 合约交易对。通常需要进行两次交易，用 OKB 换成 USDT，再换成 ETH；但在统一账户中，可以直接选择 ETH/USDT 交易对进行购买，并产生 1800 USDT的负债。在跨币种全仓模式下，合约产生了的未实现盈亏会享有一个免息额度，不仅不需要支付利息，还省下了手续费。

body:
Despite the travesty and chaos on Oro leading up to the Great Sealing, this tragic series of events does not mark the end of Oro’s story, rather, it is merely the beginning of something far greater about to unfold.  

Oro is reaching out in the dark and trying to communicate with our world. As soon as a connection is established between our own souls and those of the sleeping warriors on Oro, they can finally be awoken to fulfil their role as “Seekers” and mark a new era of life for Oro’s future. Most Seekers have lost their memories of life on Oro before the Great Sealing. They will begin their new lives after awakening on Oro, where they will fight for survival, explore their surroundings and create their own legions while striving to prove their power and loyalty to the gods in order to unveil the secrets behind the deities’ departure and solve the mystery of The Great Sealing. 

Each Seekers belongs to a different nation on Oro. The intensity of their intrinsic connection to our world varies for each Seeker depending on which part of Oro they are from. The first group of warriors to awaken belong to the Wilder Clan, a tribe whose roots lie in the South Eastern regions of Oro where they worship the gods of fire and death.

body:
20220702:

昨天居然和NWQ聊到十一点，回家之后STEPN和日记都没写。

虽然睡得晚，但是还是醒的早，看来以后想要睡眠超过8小时只能早睡。上午看完了纸钞屋，其实里面对钞票的探讨只有最后一段比较靠谱，就是黄金是不是真的并不重要，别人觉得你的是不是真的才最重要。

中午午睡了一会儿。试了一下，OUAR也可以记录。下午去浦东逛了一下，出人意料地感觉好。经济对大部分人的生活影响真的是太大了。

title: The New Creator & Ownership Economy
body:
## A primer on the state of Web3.

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*ZkS5pAms5idBlsVFauZ6cQ.png)

I strongly believe that the next wave of computing innovation along with entirely new sectors of the economy will be built on decentralized technology. This technology has rapidly evolved beyond its financial origins. The community encompasses constituencies ranging from musicians and artists to small business owners and government agencies. Smart regulation must reflect the diversity of potential users and use cases.

Decentralized technologies offer an alternative to a digital status quo that is increasingly dominated by big tech and oppressive regimes. Open, democratized systems can provide the infrastructure to power tomorrow’s economy and institutions. Realizing that potential will depend on collaboration between the government and the private sector to develop regulatory frameworks that encourage innovation while managing the risks inherent in different applications.

Before we start exploring the next iteration of the creator economy, through the lens of Web3 platforms, let’s take a step back and explore the history of the creator economy since the inception of the internet.

## Web1 | The Information Economy → Content consumers (1985)

During the first era of the internet from the 1980s through the early 2000s internet services were built on **open protocols** (e.g., TCP, IP, SMTP, HTTP). This created a stable, level playing field on which to build the ecosystem of the internet. It was during this period of innovation that many of the biggest web properties were started.

> **Web1: “Read- Only”**

*Web1* refers to the first version of the web: **read-only**. Also called ***‘The Information Economy’.*** Web1 examples are static web and personal sites, where the users’ role was mainly limited to reading the information provided by a few content producers, with no option for them to circle back to those creators. An example is AOL, which was consumption-only.

## Web2 | Creators = Bloggers → Brand representatives (2004)

During the second era of the internet from the mid-2000s to the present businesses built a second layer of proprietary, **closed protocols** on top of the internet’s *open protocols*. This has been a period of centralization, as for-profit tech companies most notably \*Google, Apple, Facebook, \*and *Amazon* built software and services that rapidly outpaced the capabilities of open protocols.

As more people started gravitating to the internet, **Web2** saw the rise of influential people who started blogging, gradually amassing significant fame and online audiences on platforms such as [MySpace](https://myspace.com/), [Blogger](https://www.blogger.com/about/?bpli=1), [Soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/) as well as Vinyl.

> **Web2: “Read → Write”**

This is the world of **Web 2.0**. As the saying goes: “If you’re not paying for it, you’re not the customer. You’re the product.”

Thereafter, Web2 creators started monetizing their audience primarily via advertising, becoming the channels for other brands — allowing creators to earn revenue through affiliate advertising and sponsorship agreements. However, they were just the conduits of these other brands and businesses with no loyal attachment to the company.

## Web3 | No more platform monopolies → Creator Ownership.

We are now in the early stages of developing **Web3**, in which communities are incentivized and rewarded for maintaining and developing core infrastructure.

In Web3, the definition of creator is changing as power dynamics shift from the *platforms to the creators and their communities*.

> Today, the creator economy is no longer just about providing value to the platforms, it’s about new forms of **direct creator-community relationships**. There is an opportunity for creators \*not only \*to offer more to their fans (including financial upside) \*but for both creators and their communities \*to finally be able to participate in the collective value that they help platforms create.

![Source: State of Crypto 2022](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*N5FR6ufSdLNPjs-VcAU4Sg.png)

### Why does it matter?

The decentralized networks of web3 offer an alternative to the broken digital status quo.

While centralization has helped billions of people get access to amazing technologies, many of which were free to use, it has also stifled innovation.

Right now, companies that own networks have unilateral power over important questions like who gets network access, how revenue is divided, what features are supported, how user data is secured, and so on. That makes it harder for startups, creators, and other groups to grow their internet presence because they must worry about centralized platforms changing the rules and taking away their audiences or profits.

> **Web3: “Read → Write → Own”**

The classic challenge of decentralized networks is that they are public goods. Without a central entity to control decisions and capture profits, it is hard to incentivize their maintenance and development. Crypto helps solve this problem through decentralized coordination and providing economic incentives for development. ***web3 will put power in the hands of communities rather than corporations.***

Decentralized networks are an important counter to the fragility of centralized applications. Decentralized systems avoid single points of failure. Decentralized networks can also neutralize the unilateral control exerted by centralized platforms.

## The New Creator Economy: A Community-owned Ecosystem

The Creator Economy refers to emerging communities of creators artists, musicians, and game developers who connect directly with their supporters and collaborate without intermediaries, enabling them to develop independent income streams.

> “The **Creator Economy** is a subset of the **passion economy** the emerging category of businesses founded by self-employed content creators, supported by the digital platforms and financial tools that make the monetization of content viable.”

> Platforms are becoming community-led where both creators and their audience members have the opportunity to have greater upside based on their contributions.

## ***Why does it matter??***

For many people, especially younger people who are spending more and more time online and in digital spaces, it is becoming increasingly popular to own digital versions of physical assets. Books, music, and movies like photographs exist as digital files saved on hard drives or in the cloud.

When you purchase a **Non-Fungible Token (NFT)**, it’s yours to control as you see fit, similar to when you buy a physical good. You can transfer it, sell it, collateralize it, lend it, or keep it for yourself to admire. Early use cases for NFTs include digital art, games, sports memorabilia, and collectibles.

**NFTs** offer creators *new ways to monetize, bypassing traditional gatekeepers and giving fans a direct stake in their success*. They’re better for creators, who can sell their work directly without having to rely on middlemen (for example, artists who used to sell their artwork in galleries that took a cut or charged a fee). And they’re better for fans because they become owners, giving them an increased stake in the artists and creators they support.

Since NFTs are verifiable digital property rights, they also have many potential applications beyond the Creator Economy

## The difference between creators and influencers

While influencers depend on brand deals, creators monetize their content directly through their audience via donations, tip jars, or paid community subscriptions.

![Source: Antler](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*EfLLPrGJ2KS5QU8n_EQeLQ.png)

**Influencers** promote brands, products, services, affiliate links, or their merchandise. For them, content is a way to increase their followers and reach which in turn increases their price on the market.

**Creators**, on the other hand, focus only on the quality of content they produce. Through educational or entertaining content they hope to meet the interest and overcome the challenges of a specific audience.

The creator economy is estimated to be at **$104.2 billion**, with a noticeable growth rate when compared to that of the [Gig Economy](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/g/gig-economy.asp) (trillion-dollar valuation in the future).

![Source: Gumroad](https://miro.medium.com/max/1204/1\*F0u6GyBRBd2JPkAGx_wJhQ.png)

Creators combine multiple software tools to assemble a plethora of revenue streams in line with their style, no matter how niche. That’s a win for creators as well as everyone else. Because creators can finally build a real career while producing content tuned to every sub-culture in the rainbow.

***Here are some notable insights about the creator economy.***

## Creator Market Size

If you consider that the Gig Economy is estimated to be valued at anywhere between **$1–4.5 Trillion by 2023** and the Creator Economy is on a similar trajectory, then we’ve got some bold growth ahead of us — to **$1 Trillion**, and beyond! \*\*Creators are businesses themselves. \*\*The faster you realize that the quicker you can jump into this exploding market.

> From social media platforms to other industries like Influencer Marketing to the more than 50 million Creators themselves to the 500+ new startups joining the scene, the Creator Economy is attracting multi-billion dollar attention.

![Source: Influencer Marketing Hub](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*xuY7rBxAF9oHxjwp0YTm3g.png)

### Creators’ Earning Power

The side-by-side comparison of Creator size, income, and engagement shows the rising control Creators have over their accounts as full-time occupations and outlets for passion.

Earning power increases with time in the industry. **46%** of Creators who have been building an audience for **4+ years earn over $20k annually** across their monetized channels.

![Source: Influencer Marketing Hub](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*fpE3MXvXaoZwe7YpRHr0mA.png)

### Measuring Success

![Source: Influencer Marketing Hub](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*T4_OXiVFQZmz3R6Th_ZE7w.png)

Though income is most important for living costs, Creators on **4 out of 7 platforms listed Engagement Rate as their top measure of success,** if they had to pick just one. Given the importance of reaching for personal branding and sponsorships, it’s no surprise that **17.11% of the Creators** key in on engagement.

![Source: Influencer Marketing Hub](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*jfAla0nZDEl6pWY4GTv1Iw.png)

### Content Creator Employees' Age Breakdown

Brands are hiring in-house content creators today and they are an integrated part of social media and marketing teams. But, these aren’t the typical content creators that you would think of for non-company-owned social media channels.

The age breakdown of content creator employees is much older with an \*\*average age of 30-40 years old \*\*definitely not Gen Z. Within the 30-40-year-old age bracket, this group accounts for **40%** of the employee content creators. ***Should more brands be skewing younger?***

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*uSYZbbnpqfhOOdeLnFFO9Q.png)

## Creators are the new founders 💫

Despite many creators facing challenges, there remains sufficient optimism for the creator economy to continue to expand. It gives new hope to people and opportunities for them to follow their passions. In this Covid-raved world, the creator economy offers unique opportunities for people to work from home and concentrate on the skills they have developed over time.

We’re at an inflection point in history where becoming a professionalized creator is one of the most desired jobs. Creators become creators because they love to create. As they grow their audience and expand their revenue channels, the burden of managing the day to day of their business grows heavier. Startups that will dominate the next stage of this evolution are ones that are centered around empowering creators to seamlessly monetize while staying focused on what they already love creating content.

> **Here is my twitter thread summarizing What is Web3 .**

[https://twitter.com/rohit_gajaraj/status/1541868809119707141?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1541868809119707141%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fcdn.embedly.com%2Fwidgets%2Fmedia.html%3Ftype%3Dtext2Fhtmlkey%3Da19fcc184b9711e1b4764040d3dc5c07schema%3Dtwitterurl%3Dhttps3A%2F%2Ftwitter.com%2Frohit_gajaraj%2Fstatus%2F1541868809119707141image%3Dhttps3A%2F%2Fi.embed.ly%2F1%2Fimage3Furl3Dhttps253A252F252Fabs.twimg.com252Ferrors252Flogo46x38.png26key3Da19fcc184b9711e1b4764040d3dc5c07](https://twitter.com/rohit_gajaraj/status/1541868809119707141?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1541868809119707141%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fcdn.embedly.com%2Fwidgets%2Fmedia.html%3Ftype%3Dtext2Fhtmlkey%3Da19fcc184b9711e1b4764040d3dc5c07schema%3Dtwitterurl%3Dhttps3A%2F%2Ftwitter.com%2Frohit_gajaraj%2Fstatus%2F1541868809119707141image%3Dhttps3A%2F%2Fi.embed.ly%2F1%2Fimage3Furl3Dhttps253A252F252Fabs.twimg.com252Ferrors252Flogo46x38.png26key3Da19fcc184b9711e1b4764040d3dc5c07)

## Notable Insights

* $800 million in venture capital has been invested into Creator Economy startups since October 2020.
* 46% of Creators \*\*who has been building an audience for **4+ years earn over $20k annually** across their monetized channels.
* We estimate the **total Creator Economy market size to be around $104.2 Billion** and on par with a substantial growth trajectory similar to the Gig Economy. That’s a future valuation of TRILLIONS of dollars.
* **72% of Creators prefer Instagram and identify it as their primary content platform.**
* Of the [surveyed Creators](https://influencers.club/2021/07/19/what-is-a-creator/#:\~:text=The%20creator%20economy%20is%20consisted,dollar%20valuation%20in%20the%20future).) that considered themselves full-time Creators, ie. content creation is their main source of income-**78% make more than $23,500 annually.**
* The power of sponsorships should not be underestimated. 77% of Creators depend on brand deals, that’s **3x as many as every other revenue source combined.**
* There is not a definite correlation between follower count and income. Between the $50–100k and $500k-1M reported income levels from creating content, there are **half a million dollars in income difference, but a difference of only 1.8K more followers.**

## The Ownership Economy

Thirty years into the development of the world wide web, a handful of companies control most user attention and advertising revenue, with closed ecosystems that hold back innovation by independent developers. The economic interests of the biggest internet platforms are poorly aligned with their most valuable contributors: their users.

Ownership has long been embraced by Silicon Valley startups to align incentives among employees through option grants. S**till, the vast majority of internet users own exactly 0% of the services they contribute to.** Creators don’t own their content **“NFTs make the internet ownable”**, 2021, developers can’t control their code, and consumers can’t influence the policies or decisions of the platforms they use.

> “The products and services that will define Web3 and the next generation of the internet are those that turn users into owners. We call this the ownership economy.” The ownership economy 2022 — Variant Fund

This scenario, which once went unquestioned, looks increasingly archaic. This is starting to change via the ownership economy often referred to as web3 with products and services that turn users into owners. What started with Bitcoin and Ethereum both of which reward participants who secure the network with their native tokens is becoming prevalent across all categories of software, from developer infrastructure and new financial markets in DeFi to consumer products, marketplaces, and social.

> Amidst all this growth, we need to take a step back and re-introduce this ecosystem through some fundamental questions: *what is the ownership economy? How big is it, and where is it headed? What trends are defining its current state and possible future?*

### What is it all about? 🤨

The ownership economy in its present form is an evolution of the *sharing economy.* This new economy \*\*\*builds on economic rewards from user participation, network effects, computing resources, community, and access to financial freedoms \*\*\*debased from traditional models.

The ownership economy gives people rights, sharing freedoms, monetization streams, and access through protocols to truly determine how they wish to participate, rather than a rigid form set by centralized systems. It means that the owner the user will determine how novel rewards, platform governance, or new forms of social capital will shape the future of user-generated value.

> Simply put: the products and services that will define web3 and the next generation of the internet are those that transform users into owners. We call this the ownership economy

### Why does it matter? - A new internet owned by users

If the last generation of software was built upon a foundation of **user-generated content**, the next generation of software will be **user-owned**, with digital ownership leveraged as a building block to enable novel user experiences. At its core, the ownership economy not only offers a powerful new tool for builders to leverage market incentives to jumpstart new networks it also holds the potential to create positive social change through the wider distribution of wealth-building assets.

> **Here is my twitter thread 🧵 summarizing what creator & ownership economy is all.**

[https://twitter.com/rohit_gajaraj/status/1541906555003514881?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1541906555003514881%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fcdn.embedly.com%2Fwidgets%2Fmedia.html%3Ftype%3Dtext2Fhtmlkey%3Da19fcc184b9711e1b4764040d3dc5c07schema%3Dtwitterurl%3Dhttps3A%2F%2Ftwitter.com%2Frohit_gajaraj%2Fstatus%2F1541906555003514881image%3Dhttps3A%2F%2Fi.embed.ly%2F1%2Fimage3Furl3Dhttps253A252F252Fabs.twimg.com252Ferrors252Flogo46x38.png26key3Da19fcc184b9711e1b4764040d3dc5c07](https://twitter.com/rohit_gajaraj/status/1541906555003514881?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1541906555003514881%7Ctwgr%5E%7Ctwcon%5Es1_&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fcdn.embedly.com%2Fwidgets%2Fmedia.html%3Ftype%3Dtext2Fhtmlkey%3Da19fcc184b9711e1b4764040d3dc5c07schema%3Dtwitterurl%3Dhttps3A%2F%2Ftwitter.com%2Frohit_gajaraj%2Fstatus%2F1541906555003514881image%3Dhttps3A%2F%2Fi.embed.ly%2F1%2Fimage3Furl3Dhttps253A252F252Fabs.twimg.com252Ferrors252Flogo46x38.png26key3Da19fcc184b9711e1b4764040d3dc5c07)

## The ownership economy is big and growing 🚀

As of April 26th, 2022, the market capitalization of the over 19,000 tokens tracked by data aggregator CoinMarketCap is **[$1.76 trillion](https://coinmarketcap.com/)**. For comparison, the market capitalization of global stock markets is over [$100 trillion](https://www.sifma.org/resources/research/research-quarterly-equities/).

The largest crypto networks by market capitalization are established layer 1 blockchains: [Bitcoin](http://bitcoin.org/) ($725 billion), which was launched in 2009, and [Ethereum](https://ethereum.org/en/) ($337 billion), which was launched in 2015. Other layer 1s in the top 20 tokens by market capitalization include [Solana](https://solana.com/), [Polkadot](https://polkadot.network/), [Terra](https://www.terra.money/), and [Avalanche](https://www.avax.network/).

![Source: Variant Fund](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*JpIkqdyxypiSPDwKt3J8zw.png)

We can also think about the scale of the ownership economy in terms of people the users who become owners of the networks they build.

## Paradigm Shifts in the Ownership Economy

Today, user ownership is transforming how people transact, invest, create, build, play, learn, communicate, and socialize.

### ✨Paradigm 1: Accessibility in the digital era shifting learned behavior

One of the key advantages of blockchain technology is the removal of intermediaries and supporting financial freedoms for individuals. While many advances have been made toward that end, without the ease of access, mass adoption cannot occur. Accessibility has remained the greatest barrier to cryptocurrency adoption and the advancement of a truly decentralized marketplace.

There has yet to be a natural on-ramp that clears the accessibility hurdle, while gradually evolving learned behavior to adopt cryptocurrency. ***Making the Digital Economy accessible and eliminating current barriers to entry that impede mass-market adoption***

### ✨Paradigm 2: The key to Ownership

The advent of the digital era has brought with it an unprecedented generation of new value. New assets and commodities have generated incredible wealth for those able to create, extract, store and trade them.

As it stands though, the largest players in Big Data are intermediaries, adding friction to ecosystems while often treating individuals solely as resources to be exploited. Custodianship of user data has remained with the companies that collect it. For the most part, individuals are being ignored when the value their data generates is distributed they have been mostly removed from the upside of this digital commodity. ***The key to individual participation in the Digital Economy will be ownership and control of their own data.***

### ✨Paradigm 3: Decentralization and WEB3

As the world works through this age of digital transformation, a massive shift in trajectory is also upon us. Since the start of the global pandemic, society has undergone a rapid acceleration in the adoption of all things digital. For the vast majority of the population though, the ability to transact in a digital form, without intermediaries or price gouging, has not occurred.

Even as users claim ownership of their previously untapped value, they still lack the ability to monetize that value through digital gateways and close the loop of direct value exchange. **Facilitating a friction-less ecosystem that empowers the users to participate in the Ownership Economy and transact in ways never seen before.**

## State of the ownership economy in 2022

![Source: Variant Fund](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*8qF0YTuSOzk4jd4l7iRosQ.png)

> Inorder to make your life easier in understanding this, I have created this infographic  :))

![Source: Own Illustration \[Gajaraj, Rohit\]](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*BCiKXa_AAnOnTux7NikGNA.png)

### What’s next? ✨

Being a creator today requires evolving from being an artist to being a founder. The job has come to encompass product management, design, community engagement, e-commerce, and data science along with being an entertainer. You have to build a team of experts and vendors to help you manage the tools to build a diversified business across platforms.

But with that diversification comes resilience. Creators become less vulnerable to shifts in priorities of the tech giants or their algorithms by owning a direct relationship with their fans. Each creator can assemble a different balance of revenue streams to match their style, no matter how niche. That’s a big win for everyone because creators catering to each of our esoteric interests can build sustainable careers. Instead of just homogeneous, lowest common denominator prime time sit-coms, we get content tuned to every sub-culture in the rainbow. Now there are finally enough creators to support a whole ecosystem of startups helping them turn their passion into their profession.

The **potential of Web3 is limitless**. With the advent of blockchain, a new era has emerged on the Internet. As such, with all of the human and financial capital inflows into the space, incredible use cases have started to gain mainstream adoption. Ownership is now extending to all kinds of products and networks.

The \*\*Ownership economy is massive and growing quickly. \*\*Many terms in addition to “the ownership economy” are used to describe how technology is empowering new ways for people to become entrepreneurs or solopreneurs. These include the passion economy, the creator economy, the empowerment economy, the freelance economy, and of course the gig economy. But no matter what you call it, it’s clear technology is creating more opportunities for people to become self-employed creators and owners.

> *‘’The new creator economy encompasses everything creators have always craved -ownership and community-led platforms where all community members are compensated for their time and contributions. Being a creator is enormously hard however we believe everyone will be a creator eventually in some capacity.’’*

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1400/1\*ZkS5pAms5idBlsVFauZ6cQ.png)

## Future projections 🔮

1. Expect next-gen financial support for creators will arise. Areas around cryptocurrency, DeFi (decentralized finance), and the NFT market will continue to grow, and so will services looking to help creators.
2. Expect many more creators to embrace NFTs in their own communities as they discover how much better they can monetize by selling digital goods directly to their fans vs banner ads and other web2 monetization methods.
3. New startups are carving out specific services from both traditional and new tech incumbents ‒ transforming how content is created, produced, financed, distributed, monetized, engaged with, and owned within digital communities.
4. New web3 users who earn tokens through games and NFTs will likely choose to save those tokens in DeFi protocols vs tradfi banks given the better rates and user experience, as new token distribution designs are boosting user loyalty.
5. Expect new platforms, new partnerships, and new ways of doing things to raise customer awareness and build new and stronger customer relationships and experiences that are truly exciting.
6. The Creator Economy is also shaping the Future of Business. If you’re not creating content, you’re consuming it. In a way, you are contributing to this business trend. The only thing that is left to be seen is if or how long it will take for the creator economy to overtake the traditional economy.
7. The Ownership economy is massive and growing quickly. Expect user ownership can jumpstart; though, sustaining it is tougher. User ownership leads to richer ecosystems of projects and contributors.

title: What's a 'Good' Explanation?
body:
## Look at your surroundings.

Now, explain how you ended up here.

Did your answer include the creation of existence, such as The Big Bang? If not, your answer is incomplete.

### Existence

Don’t be hard on yourself. Your explanation did not need to be 100% complete to suffice. This prompt is typically interpreted as a request for the most immediate and significant reasons for being here, such as: “I fell off my bike and broke my arm, so now I am in the ER”. For obvious reasons, it is impractical to describe The Big Bang and then every sequential moment that led to you falling off your bike. Nonetheless, let’s examine the reasons: (1) ain’t nobody got time for that. (2) any attempt at a complete explanation would be riddled with assumptions and inaccuracies. Nobody has observed every moment in spacetime, nor possesses the memory and processing capability to completely understand these events. The main point here is that there is a *reason for being* (not to be confused with purpose). The reason that ‘you’ exist is because your dad’s sperm fertilized your mom’s egg. Somewhere along the way, ‘you’ came into existence. However, the answer to the question “Why did you fall off your bike?” requires an infinitely precise answer in order to be 100% accurate (we obviously do not care about 100% accuracy in all cases, nor is 100% accuracy attainable). This is what we will explore in this post.

### Elements of the Mind

Okay, we do not care about The Big Bang when examining your current position in life. Instead, let’s view the most important part of reality -- your lifetime -- because everyone is the hero of their own story.

Let’s begin at the moment in which “you” obtain consciousness\* (ironically, a moment that nobody can remember). Upon accessing reality for the first time, “you” are immediately introduced to the **cause and effect protocol** of the universe, become aware of “your” existence (‘consciousness’), as well as develop an awareness of ‘thoughts’ and a procedure of thoughts (‘thinking’), achieve (some level of) control of your body and thinking (agency), and eventually learn from the environment (‘intelligence’, ‘cognition’, or as I like to say, ‘an ability to connect the dots’). In this case, the dots are bits of observed data (‘information’) interpreted as truth (‘knowledge’), which we store in our ‘memory’. The connections are a model that describes a functional i/o relation between bits (‘understanding’). Putting this all together, “we” exist as a conscious, intelligent agent of reality perceiving a sequence of moments (‘experience’) which we call life. It is almost as if reality is a Turing-Complete system (a BIG assumption) and our brains are a Turing Machine (another BIG assumption). The one thing missing in the Turing analogy is our ‘imagination’ -- the power to “see the unseen”. The reason that imagination is missing is because it is inconsistent with a Turing Machine, and thus makes humans extra interesting. The brain (our “interpretation engine”) is unique and not well understood. We are also skipping the sub-conscious element of this model for now … but will definitely discuss it later.

### Trapped In The Present

The reason that we care about history is because we can learn things that may help us in the future. We start to learn the code of reality from personal observations. Then, we learn to communicate with others, trade ideas and inspiration with them, and trust their experiences and historical accounts of reality\*\**.* After all, we physically cannot observe *everything* ourselves. Your first conscious moment is different from my first moment, and our experiences may never overlap in any meaningful way (disregarding butterfly effects for now). We cannot recount the past with 100% certainty, especially events that we did not personally observe (and even when we do have an experience … our memory can still be fuzzy). In other words, you should keep the grain of salt in your lens. There are also complex mechanisms that influence our perception (such as assumptions, cognitive bias, motivation, feelings, emotions, and biology) of which we may not be aware in the moment (not to mention the physical limitations of our human senses). Perspective is gained with an account of bias. The famous motto from The Royal Society is pertinent here -- *Nullius in Verba* -- “take nobody’s word for it”.

![A crude example of well-intentioned (perhaps) yet biased hearsay](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/2dSC4WSKaPSXEgp5J1L9A.png?height=1945&width=2085)

A historical account is more reputable when there is evidence to corroborate it’s truth. The most influential evidence garners mass consensus of its implication (a flawed mechanism for finding truth … though it does provide a clue). There is a well known saying “wisdom of the crowd”. There is also a lesser known but equally as important saying “fatality of the mob”. Consensus provides a signal on social dynamics more than anything. The objective of consensus is to win a majority, which is all about compromise\*\*\*, not truth-seeking. There is another common phrase, “history is written by the winners”, which is not an entirely true statement in its literal translation but is an attempt to describe the common biases in historical accounting. The history textbooks are missing many individual accounts, particularly on the loser’s side. This is not all the publisher’s fault because there are typically less of the losers around after a significant historical event like war, but the missing context makes the book sensitive to a combination of conformity, misattribution, and survivorship bias.

![Infinitism  -- The Ultimate Burden Of Proof -- aka The Absence of Evidence vs. Evidence of Absence Fallacy](http://www.phdcomics.com/comics/archive/phd070309s.gif)

Evidence is built through discovery -- a gain of information which improves our understanding of the circumstances which produced the evidence. It is still up to humans to deduce valid conclusions from discoveries. We commonly mistake evidence as proof. Circumstantial evidence does not have the power to prove on its own. Rather, it can indicate the likelihood of a particular events’ existence, but not accurately until we drop it into context. A proper investigation entails observing each instance of history and each piece of evidence as independent from each other and then imagining the logical sequence of events to form dependencies, hence the phrase “drawing a conclusion”. Every piece of evidence or historical account has a level of faith associated with it (and we usually realize overconfidence). For example, the discovery of fossils indicates the existence of large, now-extinct beings. And we can even imagine what they looked like! However, the fossils and present-day graphical renderings do not prove dinosaurs’ existence. The evidence simply gives us a level of confidence. A different explanation for the existence of fossils could be that a scientist synthesized fossil materials in a lab and buried them to eventually claim fame once he/she later “discovers” them and proposes a breakthrough theory of dinosaurs. However, there are sound reasons that easily disprove this explanation, namely, there is no evidence of a scientist or lab in 1677 (when Robert Plot found the first fossil) that had the capability to synthesize an organic material that could resemble the form of a fossil.

![The Gettier Problem (philosophy), Gödel’s Incompleteness Theorems (math), and Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle (science) all arrive at the same idea from different disciplines -- proof requires complete information and infinite precision. Conjecture is imminent (we settle for "beyond a reasonable doubt" in court.)](https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/proof.png)

Evidence is an empirical starting point. It exists in context. A thorough assessment of evidence addresses as much context as possible. At the same time, there will always be missing context, so we will never have a totally complete or perfectly accurate history. I call this *The* *Theory of Relative History*.

### Explanations

I once concluded that everything can be explained, so the world must be deterministic. I arrived at this conclusion after reading *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.amazon.com/Beginning-Infinity-Explanations-Transform-World/dp/0143121359)* by David Deutsch. I highly recommend reading it. In fact, it was the inspiration for this blog (if you don’t read books, then at least listen to Naval Ravikant’s *[The Beginning of Infinity](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jEmJIA0pEf0)* podcast series with Brett Hall breaking down the book). The big takeaway from the book is that omniscience is not required to have ‘creativity’ -- an ability to create new “things”. You do not need to know absolutely every fact that exists in order to understand everything that can be understood. Reality is most accurately described using good explanations, and there is an explanation for everything. The building blocks of explanations are **[First Principles](https://fs.blog/first-principles/#_ftn11)** -- namely the foundations of science (Relativity, Quantum, Evolution, Information, Computing, etc.) -- and the fuel is imagination.

> *“What I cannot create, I do not understand”*
>
> \-- Richard Feynman

Science is an error-correcting machine. It disproves explanations and forms better ones. You will find that the most impactful explanations require intense imagination because they describe ‘the seen’ in terms of ‘the unseen’. In other words, they describe things that cannot be observed. Unseen phenomena can be measured with special equipment, but we just observe the measurement readings on the equipment. For example, we can measure the temperature of an atom’s nucleus, but we cannot observe the movement of quarks which are the cause (we think) of the temperature reading that we observe. An explanation is not an explanation unless it is testable, falsifiable, and precisely describes a significant mechanism of change (cause and effect). It is our best guess. In this way, even good explanations are at risk of being inaccurate. This is okay because this is how we create new knowledge. A good explanation is our best understanding, our best description for how something works, at any given time. It is like the scientific method on steroids. A good explanation provides reasons and digs deep. It asks questions to get to the root. Try the **5 Why’s method** to improve the accuracy of an explanation.

> *“Science is a way of thinking much more than it is a body of knowledge.”*
>
> — Carl Sagan

As you can see from the bike example at the beginning, an explanation does not need to be entirely complete in order to be valuable because intelligent beings (humans) can identify patterns and make inferences. Again, a partially true, incomplete explanation can be sufficient if we only care about a certain level of accuracy. An explanation is measured by its explanatory power -- the degree to which an explanation accomplishes an objective. The objective can be to accurately describe Truth. Explanations have degrees of completeness based on the amount of information present in them\*\*\*\*. A thorough explanation leaves little to chance. A complete explanation leaves nothing to chance. The pinnacle of explanations is a perfect explanation -- 100% complete and 100% accurate. The ultimate explanation, a *Theory of Everything*, would be perfect. Many people have tried to find this explanation, such as Michio Kaku's *[The God Equation](https://www.amazon.com/God-Equation-Quest-Theory-Everything/dp/0385542747)* (I have not read yet), but none have succeeded.

The jury is still out on if a perfect explanation exists.

### Truth

Our initial guess for how knowledge exists is known as the ‘justified true belief’ theory of knowledge. This theory says that knowledge is about justifying your beliefs as true. It then goes on to say that if you accomplish this, then your belief is knowledge. This a misconception because there is no logical way to prove any bit of knowledge as Truth (with a capital ‘T’). One can provide evidence, but this is not proof. If an explanation prevails against attempts to disprove it, then it is consistent with reality and is probably considered useful. Yet, we can never know with 100% certainty that the explanation accurately describes a fundamental Truth (a “law” of nature\*\*\*\*\*) because there is always a chance that we discover new information debunking that explanation. Then, we simply come up with a better explanation.

The first step to finding truth is to develop a theory of knowledge (epistemology). I subscribe to the theory that knowledge is an interpretation of information that is accepted as truth and can be measured for accuracy and significance. This implies knowledge is subjective i.e. your truth may not be my truth.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xwFu_2fyTN7kfq6Mi8bBH.png?height=792&width=1561)

In the end, knowledge is still just an assumption. Humans seek highly objective knowledge because we get rewarded with better predictions. Nassim Taleb describes a concept of *non-observables*, in his *[Incerto](https://www.amazon.com/Incerto-Deluxe-Randomness-Procrustes-Antifragile/dp/198481981X)* (my favorite is *[The Black Swan](https://www.amazon.com/Black-Swan-Impact-Improbable-Incerto/dp/1400063515/ref=asc_df_1400063515/?tag=hyprod-20&linkCode=df0&hvadid=312106851030&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=11165397501409576070&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9010943&hvtargid=pla-330161967766&psc=1)*). There will always be unknowns and we do not know the significance of the unknowns. We don't know for sure what will effect us, kill us, or save us. It may not be real today.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/kWP9k4Mb0aJLmmm6JXgSD.png?height=697&width=1114)

Explanations can retrospectively describe causation and also fuel predictions -→ which builds knowledge -→ which inspires imagination -→ which creates explanations. These ‘creations’ bring a truth into existence that did not exist before (or at least did not exist to ‘you’). It is quite liberating when you realize that explanations are created with imagination, so in theory, you can understand anything! Knowledge is iterative. Regardless of whether or not information is infinite\*\*\*\*\*\*, knowledge is not scarce. It is the product of intelligence and unbounded imagination and is stored in memory.

Keep in mind, reality is unbiased. It is Truth. It just is\*\*\*\*\*\*\*. It is the purest form of objectivity (no interpretation necessary). Frankly, reality does not care about you (or anything). Reality is left to humans for interpretation. The most useful application of this realization is to practice acceptance because the world is not out to get you. At the same time, we can effect change in our lives. For every effect, there is a cause\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*. For every output, there is an input. You may notice the continuity of this universal model. But what happens when there is a discontinuity in the model? And what does a gap represent?

### Randomness

The answer is randomness -- an absence of information. This is where we can assign probabilities rather than determinations of the future. The important thing here is that reality is not intrinsically random or uncertain … with one theoretical exception. The only proposed natural randomness in the universe is the phenomena described by quantum mechanics -- an explanation for how matter and energy behaves as spacetime approaches zero. Even in quantum, we have some predictive ability of the probability distribution of subatomic particles in spacetime. This gets more interesting if you consider quantum randomness in a multiplicative series of moments. As you can see, each sequential moment gets increasingly difficult to predict and eventually the complexity explodes, leading most scientists to chaos theory and the multiverse\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*.

All other probability is subject to a knowledge base. This means that any likelihood which we attributed to an event’s existence is a function of our ignorance. When humans say “I am uncertain”, we are admitting that we do not know a critical piece of information that would make the Truth apparent. We can reduce uncertainty and increase the accuracy of our predictions by reducing knowledge gaps (not to be confused with information gaps). Here are two ways to reduce knowledge gaps and improve predictability:

1\.) empirical methods -- inducing a hypothesis from experience.

2\.) explanatory methods -- deducing a cause and effect relation from imagination.

These methods are most powerful when deployed in tandem.

Empirical methods infer an independent factor (causal inference) from observations or experimental results (statistics). This is useful to identify information gaps. You can gain (uncover) information by changing the conditions (i.e. varying the independent variable to see the change in the dependent variable). Here’s a hint, when correlations between events approach 100%, you may getting closer to a causal relationship (though there still may be ‘Hidden’ variables\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* which are the actual root cause). However, correlation is not causation\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\* …. so … how do you know if the measured response in the ‘effect variable’ was the result of varying the ‘cause variable’ or if the independent factors are truly independent themselves? Enter explanations.

This is how explanatory methods save the day. Explanations generate knowledge from *non-observables* -- information not apparent in the statistics -- and can implicate an unknown factor as the root cause. The reasoning offered in an explanation is based in ‘possibility’ as opposed to ‘probability’ (though probability can also appear in an explanation).

I suggest watching Vsauce's YouTube video: "[What is Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)" and Veritasium’s sister episode: "[What is Not Random](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)" to further explore randomness as a property of ignorance.

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rIy0xY99a0)

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sMb00lz-IfE)

To quickly make better predictions, acquire fundamental knowledge. Search for the fundamental factors of reality, the ones with high explanatory power. Lean on *First Principles* thinking or even better -- [Zeroth-Principles Thinking](https://medium.com/future-literacy/zeroth-principles-thinking-9376d0b7e7f5). After all, explanations are the best way to hunt the Truth. On the other hand, we will always have to make decisions with incomplete information, and thus are exposed to uncertainty … so get used to it!

I glossed over the fact that “meaning” is an important part of the brain’s interpretation engine. Sooo … what is meaning? Is meaning created or intrinsic to reality? If we assume that reality is deterministic, then can meaning exist or can we have free will? Can there be a meaning of life? If we assume that life has meaning, then what is the meaning? My best answer right now: the meaning of life is to create value. More on that in the next post…

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

\*I assume ownership of consciousness for the sake of understanding; rather, consciousness spontaneously “exists” without an agent or precise initial moment and is “you”. I enjoyed Brett Hall’s view of [ontology](https://www.bretthall.org/blog) --an explanation of being--what does it mean to exist. The model that I describe requires a definition for the concept of “you” (a whole exercise itself). I use a version of “you” that is a figment of the brain and represents an identity. “You” is awareness that exists as a state of consciousness. I also enjoyed Evan Conrad’s [article](https://evanjconrad.com/posts/how-to-feel-good) which offers a view that “you” are not your “thoughts” and suggests practical applications of this knowledge. “You” observe thoughts. At the same time, you have agency of thinking in the sense that you may be aware of a thought or feelings and its relation to “you” (as an identity that has control of an interpretation engine which does thinking procedures and serves the next thought). I would like to add that you are not your feelings. In Conrad’s view, both thoughts and feelings are real “to” you, rather than “are” or “of” you.

\*\*Yes, trust in fellow humans is risky, but the payoffs have historically outweighed the costs. There are concepts of infinite games in Game Theory which incentivize cooperation in most instances.

\*\*\*We will explore the mechanisms of consensus in another post.

\*\*\*\*Completeness is a function of access and precision. Explanations are incomplete when they are missing info. This is almost always the case when expressing explanations in spoken language because language itself is imprecise. A good question: can we know all information?

\*\*\*\*\* When describing physical reality, there is no such thing as a “law of nature” or Truth (with a capital ‘T’) since the description exists in the abstract realm of knowledge. There are just REALLY good explanations (called theories in science) that may resemble physical Truth because of their accuracy in describing and predicting phenomena, but we would never know for certain. However, there is a Truth. It exists and exists as reality. This implies the existence of False (with a capital ‘F’). Knowledge is abstract thought -- an interpretation of information which exists relative to reality (Truth/False) -- and can actually be True or False when describing knowledge, but not reality.

\*\*\*\*\*\*The more important and deeper question is whether reality is continuous or discrete. This question is most famously illustrated via [Zeno’s Paradox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeno%27s_paradoxes). Modern science does not even have a consensus on this answer. I think the answer requires a better understanding of time and information. Is information a property of reality? Does reality exist as a state of information at (that changes changes between?) moments of time? Can we create new “things” (real or abstract)? Does the set of information (as elements) grow, accumulate, remain static, or simply change?

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*I suppose the ultimate truth is whether reality itself exists or not.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*We may explore whether the inverse is necessarily true, which requires a consideration of infinity. What happens when you consider time (the temporal relationship between cause and effect)? The most convincing concept of time that I can understand is that time represents a relation between moments of reality. In this concept, a moment is a state of information (reality) and time is the relation of moments -- The God Equation -- rather than the moment. Therefore, there are instances of information, rather than instances of time. Time describes change. It *is* change. If time is a relation mapping a state of info to another state of info, which [type](https://t-redactyl.io/blog/2021/03/types-of-functions-injective-surjective-and-bijective.html) of relation is it?

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*We may address these concepts at some point. We perceive time as a sequence of moments (maybe a series when considering our memory), but time may not actually “be” an ordered sequence of moments. We do not have access to all of reality (information), which leads to gaps in information and knowledge (understanding). Also, knowledge lags information. The Truth Spectrum is not to be confused with true vs. false in logic. It is more closely related to the concept of [entropy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entropy_(information_theory)) in Information Theory.
